COURSES.name: Creating our Built Environment
COURSES.description:
An introduction to the planning, design and construction of the built environment.
Includes consideration of professional practice in architecture, construction management, historic preservation, interior design, landscape architecture, sustainability and the built environment, and urban and regional planning.
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: Admission to one of the College of Design, Construction and Planning disciplines.

COURSES.name: Geodesign Colloquium
COURSES.description: Professionals and academics introduce various geodesign topics. Presentations evoke discussion about the scope, applications, and implications of geodesign principles.

COURSES.name: Introduction to GIS I
COURSES.description: Introduces concepts and theories associated with Geographic Information Systems (GIS) as related to geodesign. Requires lectures, class assignments, and homework assignments.

COURSES.name: Methods of Inquiry for Sustainability and the Built Environment
COURSES.description: The breadth of methods of inquiry (the process of asking and then answering questions) commonly used by planners, designers and builders as well as those who study the built and managed environments.
COURSES.prerequisites: Credits: 3; Prereq: BCN 1582 or IDS 2154, or a course approved in the topic area.

COURSES.name: Sustainable Solutions for the Built Environment
COURSES.description: Uses case studies to examine how sustainability can be achieved in the built environment, from choosing materials and finishes to patterns of regional land use.
COURSES.prerequisites: Credits: 3; Prereq: BCN 1582 or IDS 2154, or a course approved in the topic area.

COURSES.name: Capstone Project in Sustainability and the Built Environment
COURSES.description: Undertake an individual project under the direction of a faculty member, with a focus on comprehensive solutions to a problem in sustainability.

COURSES.name: Undergraduate Research in Design, Construction, and Planning.
COURSES.description: Undertake firsthand, supervised research with a faculty advisor or postdoctoral or graduate student mentor. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, creativity, discovery or application. (S-U)

COURSES.name: Special Topics of Design, Construction and Planning
COURSES.description: Students will survey the economic, social and environmental impacts of a modern lifestyle. Students will find that new ways to address these issues are profitable, growing future opportunities that business
